name: Anonymous
com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9463978
It wasn't what anyone was expecting, which was entirely on purpose. If you subvert peoples' expectations that hard, you will get a lot of backlash until enough time has passed that they can appreciate what they got instead of what they wanted. To add to this, the Tanker chapter sets up what is essentially the "perfect sequel" to MGS1, which is then immediately moved away from, again entirely on purpose. This leaves the player feeling robbed of what they actually wanted, and creates a grudge against Raiden for seemingly standing in their way of a REAL sequel.

Once the initial kneejerk reaction had finally passed for everyone, reception naturally improved. New players also came into the game already knowing about Raiden and a general idea of what to expect, which makes an enormous impact on how one experiences a piece of media for the first time. On top of this primary reason, MGS1 had a fairly basic story that could be understood easily by anyone, but MGS2 is intricate and approaches a lot of ideas and themes that were unfamiliar to most players at the time. Not to say that they were not relevant to the state of the world, as they actually were, but many of those aspects simply were not known about or relevant to the average person playing. Fast forward to years later when much of what the game centers around is something the average person finally knows about and has been looking into in some fashion, and it becomes way more interesting to them.

Not to say that I was a miracle intellectual who understood it at the time of release -- I did not.

>>9471175
(PART 2)

>GABRIEL KNIGHT
An investigative detective series involving a high degree of non-linear interactivity and puzzle solving, with an emphasis on dialogue and interrogation. Also one of the earliest games to have a built-in HINT system to aid them due to its non-linear gameplay style.

>HEART OF CHINA
Pulp-inspired romp across the orient, featuring a couple unique action setpieces mixed with multiple characters to play as and multiple endings possible. A solid entry into Adventure game canon.

>GOBLIIIINS
Almost feeling like a strategy game, you use goblins with unique abilities to solve each screen and advance to the next. More puzzle game than adventure game, but a quirky and unique series that has its own fandom.

>THE BIZARRE ADVENTURES OF WOODRUFF AND THE SCHNIBBLE
A stylized adventure game memorable most of all for its sense of personality and art style that feels like a mix between Simpsons and Beavis and Butthead.

>THE COLONEL'S BEQUEST
A "whodunnit" game, where you don't even need to figure out the over-arching mystery or solve a single puzzle in order to complete. The sole purpose in the game is to find out as much information as you can about characters and their backgrounds, and keep Lara from being killed. A perfect game to spend time with on a stormy night.

>MANIAC MANSION
Early in the LucasArts pantheon, it features multiple characters who you must use to solve specific puzzles or scenarios, and features a high degree of replayability based on your party composition.

>LOOM
A fantastical adventure game centered around learning and mastering the musical instrument which allows you to, in essence, cast spells of varying kinds. A very novel approach for its reliance more on creativity than logic, knowledge, or skill.

>THE DIG
Featuring a stellar story and a breathtaking soundtrack, this feels like movie experience more than a game. Hard to forget, even harder to let go after completing.

>>9471772
>I'm playing MRA2 as well. Do you have any tip for a first-timer?
Nothing really specific to this games campaign as I haven't really bothered with finding many secrets or anything, but some basic tips on raising monsters, you may already know all this but....

Always make sure you relieve monsters "stress" and "fatigue", always let it rest obviously but also use items like oil or mintcandy to remove fatigue after training and battles. Battling itself actually helps remove monsters stress. As you accumulate larger amounts of cash, it's definitely good to prioritize buying all the more expensive stress relieving, fatigue relieving, and sleep helping items you'll see in the shop like the cups and gems, as can afford them of course, don't skip out on them, they'll make it easier for new monsters. Also don't let your monster get fat or malnourished, fat monsters get fatigued more and underweight monsters get stressed more.

Also take it easy on baby monsters, just do the most basic training until its more mature aka when Holly tells gives you that cue that it's an "important time" or whatever she says, that's when you start the coach routines

Always focus on like 3, maybe 4 main stats to train your monster in. Having a balanced monster doesn't really work because there's only so much time you can put into training during its lifespan, you want your monster to excel hard in specific areas, not be average in many areas, so take that into consideration when deciding what monster you wanna raise and how you want it to grow/what moves you want it to learn

When you're stronger and start doing sparring with the intention of learning new moves specifically, it's not really worth it unless you're gonna learn a new move, so don't bother wasting the money and time unless it says there's a chance your monster will learn a new move, and honestly I say theres no shame in saving before and restarting until you learn the move

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9468728
This.
I had been given some advice a long time ago. "When you come up with an idea, write it down and stash it in a drawer for a year or two. Then come back to it."
It's obvious this was done with REmake. Several years and tech advances mean that you could do so much more. The exact same thing applies to RE0's first bit, the train section is extremely well crafted, and the inventory system without chests actually feels really smooth when the grand total of everything you have is less then two dozen.
The problem is when you leave the train, and I'm convinced this bit was added when the devs realized that RE0 being a short game on N64 cartridges wouldn't be a problem, but would be a massive issue on Gamecube. Post-train it's a generic mansion and laboratory area. The bosses are generic giant insects + Tyrant (at least the Scorpion-train boss demanded some aiming precision) and the enemies are all things we saw in the last few games aside from the leeches or monkeys which are just dogs with extra annoyance stacked on. You're constantly backtracking three to five times just to ferry all your items from one place to another out of nagging concern that something might get used again. And while the partner AI is competent, their presence absolutely drags the already cautiously slow pace of a survival horror game down to a crawl, only picking back up whenever they're separated. All of it works, but none of it feels quite refined. Most damming is the final stint of the game and the sheer number of absolutely beautiful but absurdly empty rooms lacking puzzles, items, enemies, or anything else of note.
RE0 is a tale of two games. The Train which was the old N64 idea well refined, and the rest which is acceptable but obviously not nearly as refined.

It's very half-assed in comparison and you'd need to go a lot further to do these HD models justice, and since it's locked to emulation anyway there's really no reason not to.

>>9449094
>Hard Mode: You cannot talk about the "soul' of games running on original hardware

I wouldn't use that phrase, but there are parts of the experience that aren't just sentimental. There's two major differences, one is lacking the experience of using the hardware itself, or witnessing the art and materials included with the game. And the other is having every game ever made at instant reach and disposal. I find when I use emulators I just go down the list of noteworthy games, play for a few minutes, and then drop them. If that was your rental or purchase, you would have to give the game a better chance than that. Sometimes when I pick up emulation, particularly when trying new games, I spend more time configuring emulators than playing the games.

I've never tried one, but I really like the idea of VR frontends for emulating games, and I hope future generations endure the hassle of fucking with virtual objects even when it's not connected to any memory they were alive for.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I think we all get into emulation at one point, you can't really avoid it on 4chan, naturally you'll probably try it out.

For me it was in the early 2000s, I don't even remember where I heard about it, maybe in my many searches for old games I on the internet (I loved mega man in particular and played lots of flash recreations like a crappy mega man x flash) it may have just led me to the emulator-zone from bumping around forums. No idea. Regardless it's something we all probably did or do.

Eventually I got older and put a little more effort into it, started emulating newer systems and decided that n64 emulation was a bit of a mess with things like goemon and xbox emulation was the embodiment of "never happening." So I decided to get the real consoles. The N64 didn't last, I eventually got more consoles to play around with, PCSX2 was a thing but the real PS2 seemed more viable, all this stuff kept adding up and I emulated less and less.

Not to say I didn't put effort into emulation, dolphin, setups with sensors, different controllers, adapters to use the real controllers just a little money sinked into it - no biggie. I kept playing my real consoles more and more however. I stopped beating games thru emulators years ago, stopped getting the latest versions of emulators or bothering to boot them up at all. They just sat there while I spent more and more time with the real consoles, getting CRTs, playing with scalers, different accessories.

How cocky are we to think emulation is the be-all-end-all? It's not. We don't just play the old games, we play with the consoles, the controllers, look up information on the games, learn their secrets and study them. We see the differences between playing them on different consoles. Emulation can't recreate that. It can't even perfect it. We can fool ourselves into thinking it surpasses it with platforms thousands of times more powerful but it can never effortlessly and naturally deliver the same thing.

name: Anonymous
com: How was the gba piracy back in 2001?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
ROMs were typically numbered in order of when they were posted on the Internet, and those "scene" group dumpers' names like Eurasia, Squirrels and Trashman were included in the filenames. F-Zero (J) was among the first releases in March 2001. Some had intros and others were bad dumps which spawned No-Intro seeking to remove intros and verify untouched ROMs.
The history of the dumpers and the IRC channels they used to be in are contained in the NFO files they provided the day they dumped the ROMs. You can find all of them here in the zip files along with the "Trainer" patches for unlimited health, lives and shit:
http://advanscene.com/html/dbstart.php
I use DAMN NFO Viewer to open them, and the site tells you which ROMs had intros. The GoodGBA set has the old ROMs with those intros in them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I can recall in 2002 ordering this big bulky thing that connected to the printer port on my PC that could write to a GBA cart. For some reason I used it to install an NES emulator and a shitload of NES roms. That was how I played FF1 for the first time. I made it all the way to the volcano dungeon and then my brother and I got in a fight and he chucked my cartridge at the floor and it broke in two. It never worked after that. Good memories.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9469818
Pretty awesome. GBA was very easy to pirate for. There were bootlegs of games and even dev carts from almost day 1.

last_replies.com:
>>9469818
not sure specifically in 2001 but I recall VBA was a thing very early on and rom sites ran unchecked, I played the shit of a lot of GBA games that way, tons of shovelware I wouldn't even play today despite having complete romsets on all my flashcarts and devices
